subject: Re: [junit] Re: Using Parameters to inject data into static field
msgSnippet: What happens if you assert in the constructor that the values are non-null, and then again at the top of your test?  Which assertion fails? David
messageBody:
What happens if you assert in the constructor that the values are
non-null, and then again at the top of your test? Which assertion
fails?

David

On Tue, Jun 14, 2011 at 2:49 PM, asdflkajsd187 <willie.owens91@...> wrote:
> The parameters I'm trying to set remain null. If I change the variables to be non-static then it works, but I wanted them to be static so they could be used in a static method I'm using.
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <david@...> wrote:
>>
>> Willie,
>>
>> What happens when you run the test?  I'm surprised that doesn't work.
>>
>>    David
>>
>> On Mon, Jun 13, 2011 at 6:45 PM, asdflkajsd187 <willie.owens91@...> wrote:
>> > Hi all,
>> >
>> > I'm currently trying to use JUnit to run a number of tests using two different sets of input. However, I need this input to be static fields and it seems I can't change them if they're static. Any way around this?
>> >
>> > ex.)
>> >
>> > @RunWIth(Parameterized.class)
>> > public class testMe {
>> >   static String in1, in2;
>> >
>> >   public testMe (String one, String two) {
>> >      in1 = one;
>> >      in2 = two;
>> >   }
>> >
>> >   @Parameters
>> >   public static Collection data() {
>> >      return Arrays.asList(new Object[][] {{"a1","a2"},{"b1","b2"}};
>> >   }
>> >
>> >   ...etc.
>> > }
>> >
>> >
>> >
>> > ------------------------------------
>> >
>> > Yahoo! Groups Links
>> >
>> >
>> >
>> >
>>
>
>
>
>
> ------------------------------------
>
> Yahoo! Groups Links
>
>
>
>
